messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Randomized polynomial-time equivalence between determinant and trace-IMM equivalence tests

Paper Abstract: Abstract Equivalence testing for a polynomial family {gm}m∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑔𝑚𝑚ℕ\{g_{m}\}_{m\in\mathbb{N}} over a field 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F} is the following problem: Given black-box access to an n𝑛n-variate polynomial f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f({\mathbf{x}}), where n𝑛n is the number of variables in gmsubscript𝑔𝑚g_{m} for some m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N}, check if there exists an A∈GL​(n,𝔽)𝐴GL𝑛𝔽A\in\text{GL}(n,\mathbb{F}) such that f​(𝐱)=gm​(A​𝐱)𝑓𝐱subscript𝑔𝑚𝐴𝐱f({\mathbf{x}})=g_{m}(A{\mathbf{x}}). If yes, then output such an A𝐴A. The complexity of equivalence testing has been studied for a number of important polynomial families, including the determinant (Det) and the family of iterated matrix multiplication polynomials. Two popular variants of the iterated matrix multiplication polynomial are: IMMw,dsubscriptIMM𝑤𝑑\text{IMM}_{w,d} (the (1,1)11(1,1) entry of the product of d𝑑d many w×w𝑤𝑤w\times w symbolic matrices) and Tr-IMMw,dsubscriptTr-IMM𝑤𝑑\text{Tr}\mbox{-}\text{IMM}_{w,d} (the trace of the product of d𝑑d many w×w𝑤𝑤w\times w symbolic matrices). The families – Det, IMM and Tr-IMM – are 𝖵𝖡𝖯𝖵𝖡𝖯\mathsf{VBP}-complete under p𝑝p-projections, and so, in this sense, they have the same complexity. But, do they have the same equivalence testing complexity? We show that the answer is “yes" for Det and Tr-IMM (modulo the use of randomness). The above result may appear a bit surprising as the complexity of equivalence testing for IMM and that for Det are quite different over ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}: a randomized polynomial-time equivalence testing for IMM over ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} is known [KNST19], whereas [GGKS19] showed that equivalence testing for Det over ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} is integer factoring hard (under randomized reductions and assuming GRH). To our knowledge, the complexity of equivalence testing for Tr-IMM was not known before this work. We show that, despite the syntactic similarity between IMM and Tr-IMM, equivalence testing for Tr-IMM and that for Det are randomized polynomial-time Turing reducible to each other over any field of characteristic zero or sufficiently large. The result is obtained by connecting the two problems via another well-studied problem in computer algebra, namely the full matrix algebra isomorphism problem (𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨\mathsf{FMAI}). In particular, we prove the following: 1. Testing equivalence of polynomials to Tr-IMMw,dsubscriptTr-IMM𝑤𝑑\text{Tr}\mbox{-}\text{IMM}_{w,d}, for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 and w≥2𝑤2w\geq 2, is randomized polynomial-time Turing reducible to testing equivalence of polynomials to DetwsubscriptDet𝑤\text{Det}_{w}, the determinant of the w×w𝑤𝑤w\times w matrix of formal variables. (Here, d𝑑d need not be a constant.) 2. 𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨\mathsf{FMAI} is randomized polynomial-time Turing reducible to equivalence testing (in fact, to tensor isomorphism testing) for the family of matrix multiplication tensors {Tr-IMMw,3}w∈ℕsubscriptsubscriptTr-IMM𝑤3𝑤ℕ\{\text{Tr}\mbox{-}\text{IMM}_{w,3}\}_{w\in\mathbb{N}}. These results, in conjunction with the randomized poly-time reduction (shown in [GGKS19]) from determinant equivalence testing to 𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨\mathsf{FMAI}, imply that the four problems – 𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨𝖥𝖬𝖠𝖨\mathsf{FMAI}, equivalence testing for Tr-IMM and for Det, and the 333-tensor isomorphism problem for the family of matrix multiplication tensors – are randomized poly-time equivalent under Turing reductions.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Classification of Quadratic Forms",
        "Automorphisms of finite rings and applications to complexity of problems",
        "Equivalence of f-algebras and cubic forms",
        "Algebraic branching programs, border complexity, and tangent spaces",
        "No occurrence obstructions in geometric complexity theory",
        "Computing irreducible representations of finite groups",
        "The module isomorphism problem reconsidered",
        "Explicit n-descent on elliptic curves III. algorithms",
        "Partial derivatives in arithmetic complexity and beyond",
        "Small-depth multilinear formula lower bounds for iterated matrix multiplication with applications",
        "Computations for algebras and group representations",
        "Wildness for tensors",
        "Lower bounds for depth-4 formulas computing iterated matrix multiplication",
        "Polynomial Equivalence Problems: Algorithmic and Theoretical Aspects",
        "Ueber die darstellung der endlichen gruppen durch linearc substitutionen",
        "Quasipolynomial-time identity testing of non-commutative and read-once oblivious algebraic branching programs",
        "Geometric aspects of iterated matrix multiplication",
        "Determinant equivalence test over finite fields and over Q",
        "Geometric complexity theory and matrix powering",
        "Isomorphism problems for tensors, groups, and cubic forms: completeness and reductions",
        "Symmetry and equivalence relations in classical and geometric complexity theory",
        "Private coins versus public coins in interactive proof systems",
        "Rectangular kronecker coefficients and plethysms in geometric complexity theory",
        "Algorithms Based on *-Algebras, and Their Applications to Isomorphism of Polynomials with One Secret, Group Isomorphism, and Polynomial Identity Testing",
        "Splitting full matrix algebras over algebraic number fields",
        "Efficient algorithms for some special cases of the polynomial equivalence problem",
        "Affine projections of polynomials: extended abstract",
        "Average-case linear matrix factorization and reconstruction of low width algebraic branching programs",
        "Separation between read-once oblivious algebraic branching programs (roabps) and multilinear depth-three circuits",
        "Reconstruction of full rank algebraic branching programs",
        "Learning arithmetic circuits via partial derivatives",
        "Lower bounds for sums of products of low arity polynomials",
        "On the Power of Homogeneous Depth 4 Arithmetic Circuits",
        "On the size of homogeneous and of depth-four formulas with low individual degree",
        "Computing with Polynomials Given By Black Boxes for Their Evaluations: Greatest Common Divisors, Factorization, Separation of Numerators and Denominators",
        "Geometric complexity theory: an introduction for geometers",
        "Algebra Volumne 2: Fields with structures",
        "Geometric complexity theory I: an approach to the P vs. NP and related problems",
        "Geometric complexity theory II: towards explicit obstructions for embeddings among class varieties",
        "Determinant: Combinatorics, algorithms, and complexity",
        "Lower bounds for non-commutative computation (extended abstract)",
        "Lower Bounds on Arithmetic Circuits Via Partial Derivatives",
        "Hidden fields equations (HFE) and isomorphisms of polynomials (IP): two new families of asymmetric algorithms",
        "Improved algorithms for isomorphisms of polynomials",
        "Multi-linear formulas for permanent and determinant are of super-polynomial size",
        "Simple algebras are difficult",
        "Computing the structure of finite algebras",
        "Algorithmic properties of maximal orders in simple algebras over ℚℚ\\mathbb{Q}",
        "A survey of lower bounds in arithmetic circuit complexity",
        "Morphisms of rings and applications to complexity",
        "A Course in Arithmetic",
        "Arithmetic circuits: A survey of recent results and open questions",
        "The isomorphism problem for read-once branching programs and arithmetic circuits",
        "Completeness classes in algebra",
        "Computing the hilbert symbol, quadratic form equivalence and integer factoring"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Randomized polynomial-time equivalence between determinant and trace-IMM equivalence tests, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
